results.name: Triangular matrix T, read by rows, where row n equals row (n-1) of T^(n-1) after appending '1' for the main diagonal.
comment: Remarkably, T equals the product of these triangular matrices: T = A107867*A107862^-1 = A107870*A107867^-1 = A107873*A107870^-1; reversing the order of these products yields triangle A107876.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..140, flattened (first 31 rows from Paul D. Hanna)

maple: seq(seq(T(n,k), k=0..n), n=0..10);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Apr 13 2020
mathematica: b[n_] := b[n] = MatrixPower[Table[T[i-1, j-1], {i, n}, {j, n}], n-1];
Table[Table[T[n, k], {k, 0, n}], {n, 0, 10}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 25 2020, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: (PARI) {T(n,k) = my(A=Mat(1),B); for(m=1,n+1, B=matrix(m,m); for(i=1,m, for(j=1,i, if(j==i,B[i,j]=1, B[i,j] = (A^(i-2))[i-1,j]);)); A=B); return(A[n+1,k+1])}
(PARI) {T(n,k) = my(A=vector(n+1),p); A[1]=1; for(j=1,n-k-1, p=(n-1)*(n-2)/2-(n-j-1)*(n-j-2)/2; A = Vec((Polrev(A)+x*O(x^p))/(1-x))); A = Vec((Polrev(A) +x*O(x^p)) / (1-x) ); A[p+1]}
